affiliation.orgName: State Estimation of Discrete-Time Switched Neural Networks With Multiple Communication Channels
College of Electrical Engineering and Automation
Shandong University of Science and Technology
School of Computing, Engineering and Mathematics

biblStruct.note: received June 7, 2015; revised November 4, 2015 and January 10, 2016; accepted February 20, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the state estimation problem for a class of discrete-time switched neural networks with modal persistent dwell time (MPDT) switching and mixed time delays is investigated. The considered switching law, not only generalizes the commonly studied dwell-time (DT) and average DT (ADT) switchings, but also further attaches mode-dependency to the persistent DT (PDT) switching that is shown to be more general. Multiple communication channels, which include one primary channel and multiredundant channels, are considered to coexist for the state estimation of underlying switched neural networks. The desired mode-dependent filters are designed such that the resulting filtering error system is exponentially mean-square stable with a guaranteed nonweighted generalized H 2 performance index. It is verified that better filtering performance index can be achieved as the number of channels to be used increases. The potential and effectiveness of the developed theoretical results are demonstrated via a numerical example. Index Terms-Generalized H 2 performance, mixed time delays, modal persistent dwell time (MPDT), multiple communication channels, random measurement losses, switched neural networks.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: S TUDIES on neural networks have spanned for quite a few decades, which are mainly motivated by their potential applications in various fields, such as robotic control, fault detection, system identification, and image restoration [1]-[4]. In the implementation of neural networks, it has been recognized that undesirable time-delay dynamics are frequently encountered due to the finite speed of signal propagation [5]. The resulting neural networks with all kinds of time delays Manuscript

have been widely investigated, and many important results have been reported in [6]- [10]. Besides, many neural networks consist of a finite set of modes that switch according to internal evolution and external stimulation, and such switching can often be modeled to be stochastic or even nondeterministic. In the field of switched systems itself, two classes of nondeterministic switching signals, i.e., dwell time (DT) and average DT (ADT) switching, have been intensively investigated (see [11]- [15]). Also, a wealth of literature has appeared for the corresponding switched neural networks with or without time delays, with respect to the fundamental stability analysis [7], [16], [17] and state estimation that is relatively more challenging (see [8], [18]- [20]). Recently, in [21], it has been well argued that, the so-called persistent DT (PDT) switching is actually more general than the DT switching and ADT switching. However, the generality drastically causes that the control issues on the corresponding switched systems are much difficult to cope with. Up to now, primary works on the PDT switched systems are merely focused on the stability analysis without parameterizing the DT and the period of persistence (two parameters defining such a class of PDT switching (see [21]- [23]) and the references therein).

In addition, the communication imperfection of data losses or even channel disconnection in neural networks is not avoidable, which has motivated great research efforts during the past years (see [24], [25]) to mention a few. So far, almost all the studies have been directed toward the analysis and synthesis issues of neural networks with random measurement losses over a single channel [26], [27]. A universal way for handling the random measurement losses over a single channel is to utilize the Bernoulli distributed white sequence specified by a conditional probability distribution in the measurement description (see [28]- [31]). In practical neural networks, however, more than one channel is highly likely simultaneously available, which will reduce the influence of measurement losses and even the disconnection of the single channel in the transmission network, see the applications in neural networks [32], [33]. Therefore, it will be of great necessity and significance to consider multiple communication channels in the studies of diverse issues for improving the system performance. Unfortunately, so far, such a problem encountered with multiple communication channels has not been investigated yet and remains challenging in the area of neural networks.

On the other hand, state estimation is another crucial problem in the studies on neural networks, and a variety of 2168-2267 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

performance requirements have been proposed for the state estimation issues in the literature of neural networks, such as H ∞ sense [34], [35], generalized H 2 sense [18], [35], and passivity [20]. Recent years have also witnessed the advances on state estimation of neural networks with switching characteristics governed by DT or ADT switching signals [8], [17], [18], [37]. Note that for the sake of less conservatism, the mode-dependent estimators are more preferable, but a drawback is that only a weighted disturbance attenuation index can be obtained with a weaker attenuation property, which is not desired when compared with the traditional nonweighted ones of an explicit physical sense. Furthermore, as far as the switched neural networks with PDT switching are concerned, surprisingly, no results on the state estimation issue are available, and no attempts of using multiple communication channels for evaluating the performance benefits are initiated.

In this paper, we aim at addressing the state estimation problem for a class of discrete-time switched neural networks with modal PDT (MPDT) and mixed time delays in generalized H 2 sense. Sufficient conditions are presented to ensure that the resulting estimation error system is exponentially mean-square stable and has a nonweighted generalized H 2 disturbance attenuation level. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.

1) A more general class of switching signals, the MPDT switching is considered in the area of neural networks with switching characteristics rather than the DT or ADT switching often studied previously.

2) The data transmission among network nodes is considered to be with multiple communication channels (containing one primary channel and multiredundant channels in this paper) as a first attempt. The random measurement losses, occurring either in the primary channel or in some redundant channel, are modeled, respectively, by Bernoulli distribution and multinomial distribution. 3) A nonweighted generalized H 2 disturbance attenuation performance is established, contrasting with the weighted one in the existing literature of switched neural networks. Moreover, an interesting phenomenon in achieving a better disturbance attenuation performance index while the number of redundant channels increases is observed, which is a finding that has never been reached on state estimation problems of switched neural networks. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the model description of the underlying switched neural networks is introduced and some preliminaries are given for problem formulation. The stability and generalized H 2 performance analysis are discussed, and the generalized H 2 estimator design for the switched neural networks is given in Section III. A numerical example is provided to verify the validity of theoretical results in Section IV, and Section V summarizes the conclusions of this paper.

Notations: The notations used in this paper are standard. The superscript "T" stands for matrix transposition, R n denotes the n dimensional Euclidean space, the notation • refers to the Euclidean vector norm. The R+ and Z+ denote the set of non-negative real numbers and set of non-negative integers, respectively; and Z ≥s 1 and Z [s 1 ,s 2 ] denote the sets {k ∈ Z+ |k ≥ s 1 } and {k ∈ Z+ |s 1 ≤ k ≤ s 2 }, respectively, for some s 1 , s 2 ∈ Z+ . l 2 [0, ∞) is the space of summable infinite sequence over [0, ∞). Pr{Q} means the occurrence probability of the event "Q" and E{S} stands for the mathematical expectation of S. Given two symmetric matrices A, B, the inequality A ≺ ( ) B means that A -B is negative (semi) definite. In addition, in symmetric block matrices or long matrix expressions, we use to denote the terms which can be easily reproduced by symmetry. diag{• • • } stands for a block-diagonal matrix, and [C; D] represents [C T D T ] T . I and 0 represent, respectively, identity matrix and zero matrix with appropriate dimensions.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Consider the following discrete-time switched neural networks with mixed time delays:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ x(k + 1) = A θ(k) x(k) + B θ(k) f (x(k)) + C 2,θ(k) π m=1 ϕ m h(x(k -m)) + C 1,θ(k) g(x(k -d θ(k) (k))) + D 1,θ(k) ω(k) y(k) = E θ(k) x(k) z(k) = F θ(k) x(k) x(ι) = ψ(ι), -d max ≤ ι ≤ 0, ι ∈ Z+ (1) where x(k) [ x 1 (k) x 2 (k) • • • x n (k) ] T ∈ R n x
div.p: is the state vector with n x neurons, y(k) ∈ R n y is the output vector, z(k) ∈ R n z represents the linear combination of the neuron states to be estimated, ω(k) ∈ R n ω denotes the external disturbance belonging to l 2 [0, ∞), and ψ(ι) is a given initial condition sequence. f (x(k))
div.formula: f 1 (x 1 (k)), . . . , f n x (x n x (k))] T ∈ R n x , g(x(k)) [g 1 (x 1 (k)), . . . , g n x (x n x (k))] T ∈ R n x , and h(x(k)) [h 1 (x 1 (k)), . . . , h n x (x n x (k))] T ∈ R n x
div.p: are the nonlinear neuron activation functions. θ(k) is a switching signal that will be introduced later. d θ(k) (k) denotes the mode-dependent discrete-time delays satisfying 0
div.formula: ≤ d min ≤ d θ(k) (k) ≤ d max ,
div.p: where d min and d max are constant positive scalars representing the lower and upper bounds of discrete-time delays for any mode θ(k), respectively, while the positive scalar π characterizes the upper bound of distributed time delays satisfying π < +∞. The parameter ϕ m is introduced here to model two practical situations, i.e., the term ϕ m = 1 represents that the signal transmission contains both propagation delays and distortion, whereas the term ϕ m = 1 means that only the propagation delays are included in the signal transmission. A θ(k) diag{a 1,θ(k) , a 2,θ(k) , . . . , a n,θ(k) } describes the rate in which each neuron resets its potential to the resting state in isolation when disconnected from the networks and external inputs; B θ(k) , C 1,θ(k) , and C 2,θ(k) are the connection weight matrix, the delayed connection weight matrix, and the distributively delayed connection weight matrix, respectively; D 1,θ(k) , E θ(k) , and F θ(k) are constant matrices with appropriate dimensions.
Throughout this paper, the following assumptions are given for the neuron activation functions.
Assumption 1: For i ∈ {1, 2, . . . , n x }, the neuron activation functions f i (•), g i (•), and h i (•) in (1) are continuous and bounded.
Assumption 2 [10]: The constant ϕ m ≥ 0 satisfies the following convergent conditions:
div.formula: π m=1 ϕ m < +∞ and π m=1 mϕ m < +∞.
div.p: Remark 1: Note that in this paper, the bounded distributed time delays are taken into account [as expressed in (1)] in that an amount of parallel pathways of a variety of axon sizes and lengths are presented, which is the spatial nature of neural networks. Assumption 1, together with Assumption 2, ensures that the term π m=1 ϕ m h(x(km)) is convergent, which is a prerequisite for later developments.

The switching signal θ(k) is a piecewise constant function of time k, taking values in a finite set L = {1, . . . , N}, where N > 1 is the number of subsystems. Also, for a sequence of switching times satisfying 0

is continuous from right everywhere and may be either autonomous or controlled. The switching signal θ(k) is assumed to be unknown a priori, but its instantaneous value is available in real time. When k ∈ [k s , k s+1 ), we say that the θ(k s )th subsystem is active. In addition, when θ(k) = i ∈ L, we use the matrices
div.formula: (A i , B i , C 1,i , C 2,i , D 1,i , E i , F i )
div.p: which are known real constant matrices with appropriate dimensions to denote the ith subsystem. In this paper, we focus our study of system (1) on a class of switching signals with MPDT switching. Combining the definition on PDT in [23], the concept of MPDT is given as follows.

Definition 1: Consider system (1) and switching instants k 0 , k 1 , . . . , k s , . . . with k 0 = 0. A positive constant τ i is said to be the MPDT if there exists an infinite number of disjoint intervals of length no smaller than τ i on which θ is constant at ith subsystem, k s+1k s ≥ τ i , and consecutive intervals with this property are separated by no more than T, where T is called the period of persistence.

Remark 2: It can be concluded from Definition 1 that, within the "period of persistence" T, the switching among the subsystems can be arbitrary, and the running time of any activated subsystem will be all less than τ i . In addition, if T ≡ 0, the resulting switching will be equivalent to the modal DT (MDT) switching; if T → ∞, then the switching will be equivalent to the weak MDT switching. The readers can refer to [23] for more details.

According to the definition of MPDT switching, we would further take advantage of a concept on switching stage (proposed in [36]) that is an interval consisting of the running time (τ i -portion) of a certain subsystem and the period of persistence (T-portion). In the τ i -portion, one subsystem is activated and the running time is at least τ i , ∀i ∈ L. Let the actual running time of the T-portion at the pth stage be denoted as T (p) , p ∈ Z ≥1 , then it holds
div.formula: T (p) := G k s p +1 ,k s p+1 r=1 T θ(k sp+r ) ≤ T (2)
div.p: where T θ(k sp+r ) (less than τ i by Definition 1) denotes the running time of the activated subsystem at the switching instant The more intuitive explanation on the portion wise splitting idea can be seen in [36, Fig. 1]. Suppose that multiple communication channels exist in the transmission network. Letting ỹ(k) denote the actual output to the estimator to be designed, we have
div.formula: k s p +r ∈ [k s p +1 , k s p+1 ), r ∈ Z ≥1 ,
ỹ(k) = δ θ(k) (k)y(k) + D 2,θ (k) ω(k) + 1 -δ θ(k) (k) β θ(k) (k)σ θ(k) (k)y(k) (3
div.p: where D 2,θ(k) is a constant matrix with appropriate dimensions. The stochastic variable δ θ(k) (k), which is used to describe the data transmission over the primary channel, is assumed to be subject to Bernoulli distribution taking values on 0 and 1 with
div.formula: Pr δ θ(k) (k) = 1 = δ θ(k) , Pr δ θ(k) (k) = 0 = 1 -δ θ(k)
div.p: where δ θ(k) ∈ [0, 1]. The data transmission over some redundant channel is governed by both the stochastic variables σ θ(k) (k) and β θ(k) (k). Specifically, σ θ(k) (k) satisfies a multinomial distributed sequence defined as
div.formula: σ θ(k) (k) σ θ(k),1 (k), σ θ(k),2 (k), . . . , σ θ(k),h (k) with Pr σ θ(k) (k) = 1 Pr σ θ(k),ρ (k) = 1, σ θ(k),q (k) = 0 ρ = 1, 2, . . . , h, q = ρ = σ θ(k),ρ(4)
div.p: where σ θ(k),ρ ∈ [0, 1], ρ = 1, 2, . . . , h, and the scalar h denotes the number of redundant channels contained in the transmission network. In addition, according to the properties of multinomial distribution, we have h ρ=1 σ θ(k),ρ = 1 and
div.formula: h ρ=1 σ θ(k),ρ (k) = 1. Moreover, as σ θ(k),ρ (k) = 1, σ θ(k),q (k) = 0, ρ = 1, 2, . . . , h, q = ρ
div.p: , it means that only the ρth redundant channel is activated at the current time k. Also, β θ(k) (k) is assumed to be subject to Bernoulli distribution taking values on 0 and 1 with
div.formula: Pr β θ(k) (k) = 1 = β θ(k) , Pr β θ(k) (k) = 0 = 1 -β θ(k)
div.p: where β θ(k) (k) ∈ [0, 1]. Throughout this paper, the stochastic variables δ θ(k) (k) and β θ(k) (k) are assumed to be mutually independent. In addition, denote
div.formula: h ρ=1 σ θ(k),ρ (k), we have E δ θ(k) (k) = δ θ(k) , E δ 2 θ(k) (k) = δ θ(k) E β θ(k) (k) = β θ(k) , E β 2 θ(k) (k) = β θ(k) E σ θ(k),ρ (k) = σ θ(k),ρ E σ 2 θ(k),ρ (k) = σ θ(k),ρ + 2 - σ 2 θ(k),ρ .
div.p: Remark 3: It is worth noting that, the multiredundant channels are imported in (3) as a first attempt by using the stochastic variable σ θ(k) (k) which satisfies the multinomial distribution. In particular, at each time instant, if δ θ(k) (k) = 1 and β θ(k) (k) = 1 or 0, the measurement output is normal through the primary channel; and if δ θ(k) (k) = 0 and β θ(k) (k) = 1, the measurement output is normal through some redundant channel, which is determined by the value of σ θ(k),ρ (k) in ( 4), and in this case, only one redundant channel is activated in terms of the characteristic of multinomial distribution sequences σ θ(k) (k); while if δ θ(k) (k) = 0 and β θ(k) (k) = 0, the measurement losses occur, which implies that only noises are contained in (3). Hence, the influences of measurement losses occurring in (3) randomly should be weakened via the proposed multiple communication channels design approach, and the effectiveness of it will be demonstrated in Section IV.
Here, we are interested in designing the following full-order estimator for system (1):
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ x f (k + 1) = A f θ(k) x f (k) + B f θ(k) ỹ(k) z f (k) = C f θ(k) x f (k) x f (ι) = κ(ι), -d max ≤ ι ≤ 0, ι ∈ Z+ (5) where x f (k) ∈ R n x , z f (k) ∈ R n z ,
div.p: are the estimator state and output vectors, respectively, and κ(ι) is the initial estimator state. The matrices 1), (3), and (5) that an augmented system is given by:
div.formula: A f θ(k) , B f θ(k) , and C f θ(k) are the estimator gains to be determined. Denote x(k) [ x T (k) x T f (k) ] T , e(k) z(k) -z f (k), Ĩ1 [ 0 I ] T , and Ĩ2 [ I 0 ]. For ∀θ(k) = i ∈ L, it follows from (

⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ x(k + 1) = Ãi x(k) + {δ i (k) -δ i } Ĩ1 B f i E i Ĩ2 x(k) + Bi f Ĩ2 x(k) + C1,i g Ĩ2 x(k -d i (k)) + C2,i π m=1 ϕ m h Ĩ2 x(k -m) + (1 -δ i (k))β i (k)σ i,ρ (k) -(1 -δ i )β i σ i,ρ × Ĩ1 B f i E i Ĩ2 x(k) + Di ω(k) e(k) = Fi x(k)(6)
div.p: where
div.formula: Ãi A i 0 δ i B f i E i + (1 -δ i )β i σ i,p B f i E i A f i Bi B i 0 , C1,i C 1,i 0 , C2,i C 2,i 0 Di D 1,i B f i D 2,i
div.p: , Fi
div.formula: F T i -C f i T T .
div.p: Before ending this section, let us recall the following definitions which will be used in the next section.
Definition 2: The augmented system ( 6) is said to be exponentially mean-square stable with ω(k) ≡ 0 under switching signal θ(k), if there exist constants φ > 0 and ∈ (0, 1), such that
div.formula: E x(k) 2 ≤ φ k-k 0 x(k 0 ) 2 L , ∀k ∈ Z ≥k 0 where x(k 0 ) 2 L sup k 0 -d max ≤s≤k 0 E{ x(s) 2 }
div.p: and is called the decay rate.

Definition 3: Given a scalar γ > 0, the augmented system ( 6) is said to be exponentially mean-square stable with a generalized H 2 disturbance attenuation level γ if under switching signal θ(k), it is exponentially mean-square stable in the case of ω(k) ≡ 0 and under zero initial condition sup
div.formula: ∀k≥k 0 E e(k) 2 < γ 2 ∞ k=k 0 E ω(k) 2 holds for all nonzero ω(k) ∈ l 2 [0, ∞).
div.p: Thus, considering system (1) subject to MPDT switching and actual output model (3) with multiple communication channels subject to random measurement losses, the purpose of this paper is to design a mode-dependent estimator in the form of ( 5) such that the augmented system ( 6) is exponentially mean-square stable and has a nonweighted generalized H 2 noise attenuation performance index.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: This section is dedicated to presenting the sufficient conditions under which the augmented system ( 6) is exponentially mean-square stable and achieves a prescribed nonweighted generalized H 2 performance index. In what follows, we shall first introduce some lemmas that will be used in deriving our main results in this paper.
Lemma 1 [9]: n x , the neuron activation functions satisfy
div.formula: Suppose that = diag{λ 1 , λ 2 , . . . , λ n x } > 0, = diag{ι 1 , ι 2 , . . . , ι n x } > 0, = diag{ς 1 , ς 2 , . . . , ς n x } > 0. For s = 0, s ∈ R, i = 1, 2, . . . ,

l - i ≤ f i (s) s ≤ l + i , v - i ≤ g i (s) s ≤ v + i , ξ - i ≤ h i (s) s ≤ ξ + i where l - i , l + i , v - i , v + i , ξ - i , and ξ + i are constant scalars, then Ĩ2 x(k) f Ĩ2 x(k) T L 1 -L 2 Ĩ2 x(k) f Ĩ2 x(k) ≤ 0 (7) Ĩ2 x(k) g Ĩ2 x(k) T ϒ 1 -ϒ 2 Ĩ2 x(k) g Ĩ2 x(k) ≤ 0 (8) Ĩ2 x(k) h Ĩ2 x(k) T 1 - 2 Ĩ2 x(k) h Ĩ2 x(k) ≤ 0(9)
div.p: where
div.formula: L 1 diag l + 1 l - 1 , l + 2 l - 2 , . . . , l + n x l - n x L 2 diag l + 1 + l - 1 2 l + 2 + l - 2 2 , . . . , l + n x + l - n x 2 ϒ 1 diag v + 1 v - 1 , v + 2 v - 2 , . . . , v + n x v - n x ϒ 2 diag v + 1 + v - 1 2 , v + 2 + v - 2 2 , . . . , v + n x + v - n x 2 1 diag ξ + 1 ξ - 1 , ξ + 2 ξ - 2 , . . . , ξ + n x ξ - n x 2 diag ξ + 1 + ξ - 1 2 , ξ + 2 + ξ - 2 2 , . . . , ξ + n x + ξ - n x 2 .
div.p: Remark 4: As pointed out in [9], the constants
div.formula: l - i , l + i , v - i , v +
div.p: i , ξ - i , and ξ + i in Lemma 1 can be positive, negative, or zero. Therefore, the resulting neuron activation functions could be nonmonotonic, and are more general than the usual sigmoidtype conditions and the recently frequently used Lipschitz-type conditions. Such a presentation is very precise to provide a quantification of the lower and upper bounds on the neuron activation functions, which will reduce the conservatism of the theoretical results in this paper.

Lemma 2 [10]: Let Q ∈ R n×n be a positive semidefinite matrix, x i ∈ R n be vectors, and a i ≥ 0 (i = 1, 2, . . . , m) be scalars. If the sequences concerned are convergent, then the following inequality holds:
div.formula: m i=1 a i x i T Q m i=1 a i x i ≤ m i=1 a i m i=1 a i x T i Qx i .
div.p: We are now ready to give the first result in this paper on stability and generalized H 2 performance analysis for system (6) in the following theorem.
Theorem 1: Consider the augmented system (6), and let

Proof: First, to establish the generalized H 2 performance index for the augmented system (6), consider the following Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional:
div.formula: V i (x k , k) = 4 z=1 V z,i (x k , k) where V 1,i (x k , k) xT (k)P i x(k) V 2,i (x k , k) k-1 s=k-d i (k) g T Ĩ2 x(s) Q i,s g Ĩ2 x(s) V 3,i (x k , k) k-d min s=k-d max +1 k-1 m=s g T Ĩ2 x(m) Qi,m g Ĩ2 x(m) V 4,i (x k , k) π m=1 ϕ m k-1 s=k-m h T Ĩ2 x(s) Z i,s h Ĩ2 x(s) with Q i,s (1 -α i ) k-s-1 Q i , Qi,m (1 -α i ) k-m-1 Q i , and Z i,s (1 -α i ) k-s-1 Z i .

Now, calculating the difference of V z,i (x k , k) along the trajectory of the augmented system (6), z = 1, . . . , 4, and taking the mathematical expectation, we have

Remark 5: In Theorem 1, when considering the multiple communication channels contained in the transmission network, the exponentially mean-square stability criterion is developed for a class of discrete-time switched neural networks with MPDT switching and mixed time delays. The parameters α i and μ i are mode-dependent, which will reduce the conservatism to find feasible solutions of the desired estimators in the scheme of MPDT switching for the system than using α and μ corresponding to the scheme of PDT switching [36]. Furthermore, with the aid of the derivations in ( 26)-( 28), a nonweighted generalized H 2 disturbance attenuation performance index is obtained contrasting with the weighted one in the existing literature of switched neural networks [8], [18], [20].

Having dealt with the estimation performance analysis in Theorem 1, the generalized H 2 estimator design will be carried out for the underlying switched neural networks (1) with MPDT switching and mixed time delays. The existence conditions on the desired generalized H 2 estimators are given in the following theorem.
Theorem 2: Consider the augmented system (6), and let γ > 0,

By Theorem 1, the corresponding augmented system ( 6) is exponentially mean-square stable for any switching signals with MPDT satisfying (13) and has a nonweighted generalized H 2 performance index γ no .

In addition, from (35), the mode-dependent estimator gains are given by (33). This completes the proof. Remark 6: It is noted that the conditions ( 30)- (32) given in Theorem 2 are convex in the scalar γ 2 . Hence, the estimator gains with optimal generalized H 2 performance can be determined by solving the following convex optimization problem: min γ s.t. ( 30)- (32).
Moreover, if the above optimization problem admits a solution γ * , then the optimal nonweighted generalized H 2 performance is γ * no = γ * μ (T+1/τ min +T) max μ (T+1) max .

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: Consider the switched neural networks (1) with three neurons and two modes, where the system parameters for each mode are given as follows, Mode 1:
In addition, we suppose that six redundant channels are imported in (3), i.e., h = 6 in (4), and the parameters belonging to the measurement output y(k) are given as follows:
The nonlinear neuron activation functions are assumed to be ⎡
respectively, which have been used in [20]. By Lemma 1, it is straightforward to verify that

The purposes here are to design the mode-dependent estimators for the presented discrete-time switched neural networks with mixed time delays and multiple communication channels subject to random measurement losses, and find out the switching signals with minimal MPDT, such that the augmented system is exponentially mean-square stable and achieves a nonweighted generalized H 2 performance index. The less conservatism of the MPDT switching scheme, together with the effectiveness of multiple communication channels design approach will be demonstrated by comparison, respectively.

Suppose that the mode-dependent discrete time-varying delays satisfy 2 ≤ d 1 (k) ≤ 4 and 1 ≤ d 2 (k) ≤ 3, respectively. The upper bound of the distributed delays is π = 2, let ϕ m = (0.9) m , then it can be verified that φ = 1.71. In addition, the conditional probabilities representing the occurrences of normal output and measurement losses for the primary channel and six redundant channels are taken as

By solving the optimization problem given in Remark 6, the optimum of (μ i , α i ), i = 1, 2, can be obtained [denoted as (μ * i , α * i ), i = 1, 2], and the feasible estimator gains associated with (μ * i , α * i ) can be solved. First, to illustrate the advantages of the adopted MPDT switching scheme, Table I shows the comparison of the obtainable minimum MPDT and PDT in ensuring the feasible solution of the estimator while solving the optimization problem listed in Remark 6 (note that the minimum PDT can be obtained from a counterpart problem when removing the mode-dependency of MPDT, i.e., setting α * i ≡ α, μ * i ≡ μ). It can be seen from the comparison that eliminating the restriction of PDT has given rise to a shorter τ * 2 . On the other hand, considering different numbers of redundant channels contained in the transmission network, the optimal nonweighted generalized H 2 performance indices are computed in Table II for different T, where h = 0 represents that only single channel is available. As shown in Table II, it can be obviously seen that the more redundant channels are considered in the transmission network, the better performance index γ * no achieves. On the other hand, for a fixed number of redundant channels, the achieved nonweighted generalized H 2 performance becomes better when the length of T-portion containing fast switching is shorter. In addition, the performance levels will be worse as the values of δ i and σ i,j become smaller, which means that the probability of occurring packet losses is larger. This observation is quite intuitive and obvious, therefore is not verified here.

Designating τ 1 = 5 > τ * 1 , τ 2 = 4 > τ * 2 as T = 3, it follows from ( 22) that the decay rate = 0.8724 < 1, Then, applying the obtained estimator gains, the trajectories of state, its estimation and its estimation error are presented in Fig. 2. Also, the output, its estimation and its estimation error are shown in Fig. 3. It can be seen from Figs. 2 and 3 that the designed estimator is effective in ensuring a satisfactory tracking in the presence of the faster switching during the period of persistence, the random measurement losses and the mixed time delays for the underlying discrete-time switched neural networks.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The mode-dependent generalized H 2 estimation problem has been investigated for a class of discrete-time switched neural networks with MPDT switching and mixed time delays. Unlike the PDT switching scheme, MPDT switching is general in that all the DT in the τ i -portion can be inequivalent depending on the system modes. The multiple channels including one primary channel and multiredundant channels subject to random measurement losses have been considered simultaneously in the transmission network. The sufficient conditions on the existence of the desired mode-dependent estimators, have been established such that the augmented system is exponentially mean-square stable and achieves a guaranteed nonweighted generalized H 2 noise attenuation performance. It has been demonstrated that the achieved generalized H 2 performance via the obtained estimators is better when the multiple communication channels design approach is applied. The methodologies and techniques developed in this paper are expected to be extended into the control or estimation issue of general switched systems in the multiple communication channels scenario.
